qas.question: What did defeating Napoleon leave Britain without?
Why did Britain adopt the role of Global Policemen?
Britain adopting the role as global policeman is known as
What was Britain's foreign policy called?
Britain's dominant position in the world trade allowed them to do what?

answers.text: effectively controlled the economies of many nominally independent countries, such as China, Argentina and Siam

context: In Britain's "imperial century", victory over Napoleon left Britain without <a0_0>any serious international rival<a0_0/>, other than Russia in central Asia. <a1_0>Unchallenged at sea<a1_0/>, Britain adopted the role of global policeman, a state of affairs later known as the <a2_0>Pax Britannica<a2_0/>, and a foreign policy of "<a3_0>splendid isolation<a3_0/>". Alongside the formal control it exerted over its own colonies, Britain's dominant position in world trade meant that it <a4_0>effectively controlled the economies of many nominally independent countries, such as China, Argentina and Siam<a4_0/>, which has been generally characterized as "informal empire". Of note during this time was the Anglo-Zulu War, which was fought in 1879 between the British Empire and the Zulu Empire.
